questions.stem: Match the three types of data ingest with an appropriate source of training data.

options.title: Streaming (BigQuery), structured batch (Pub/Sub), unstructured batch (Cloud Storage)

options.title: Streaming batch (Dataflow), structured batch (BigQuery), stochastic (App Engine)
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. These are just made up terms.

options.title: Streaming (Pub/Sub), structured batch (BigQuery), unstructured batch (Cloud Storage)
options.rationale: Correct! On Google Cloud, the three types of data ingestion map to three different products. If you are ingesting streaming data, use Pub/Sub. If you are ingesting structured data directly into your ML model, use BigQuery, and if you are transforming data from training so that you can train on it later, read from Cloud Storage.

questions.stem: Which of the following models are susceptible to a feedback loop? Check all that apply.

options.title: A book-recommendation model that suggests novels its users may like based on their popularity (i.e., the number of times the books have been purchased).
options.rationale: Correct! Book recommendations are likely to drive purchases, and these additional sales will be fed back into the model as input, making it more likely to recommend these same books in the future.

options.title: A housing-value model that predicts house prices, using size (area in square meters), number of bedrooms, and geographic location as features.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. A house's location, size, or number of bedrooms cannot be quickly changed in response to price forecasts, which makes a feedback loop unlikely. However, there is potentially a correlation between size and number of bedrooms (larger homes are likely to have more rooms) that may need to be analyzed.

options.title: A face-attributes model that detects whether a person is smiling in a photo, which is regularly trained on a database of stock photography that is automatically updated monthly.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. There is no feedback loop here, because model predictions don't have any impact on the photo database. However, versioning of the input data is a concern here, because these monthly updates could potentially have unforeseen effects on the model.

options.title: An election-results model that forecasts the winner of a mayoral race by surveying 2% of voters after the polls have closed.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. If the model does not publish its forecast until after the polls have closed, its predictions cannot affect voter behavior.

options.title: A traffic-forecasting model that predicts congestion at highway exits near the beach, using beach crowd size as one of its features.
options.rationale: Correct! Some beachgoers are likely to base their plans on the traffic forecast. If there is a large beach crowd and traffic is forecast to be heavy, many people may make alternative plans. This may depress beach turnout, resulting in a lighter traffic forecast, which then may increase attendance, and the cycle repeats.

options.title: A university-ranking model that rates schools in part by their selectivity (the percentage of students who applied that were admitted).
options.rationale: Correct! The model's rankings may drive additional interest to top-rated schools, increasing the number of applications they receive. If these schools continue to admit the same number of students, selectivity will increase (the percentage of students admitted will go down). This will boost these schools' rankings, which will further increase prospective student interest, and so on…

questions.stem: What is training skew caused by?

options.title: The Cloud Storage you load your data from in the training environment  is physically closer than the Cloud Storage you load your data from in the production environment.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. The distance of where the data is stored to the processing device does not impact prediction performance.

options.title: Starting and stopping of the processing when training the model.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. Starting and stopping the processing makes no difference to the training.

options.title: Your development and production environments are different, or different code is used in the training environment  than in the development environment.
options.rationale: Correct! Different versions may cause predictions to be significantly slower or consume more memory in the training environment  than in the development environment. Different code may result in different performance.

options.title: The prediction environment is slower than the training environment.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. Training may take longer in development than in production, but the training is the same.

questions.stem: Suppose you are building an ML-based system to predict the likelihood that a customer will leave a positive review. The user interface that customers leave reviews on changed a few months ago, but you don't know about this. Which of these is a potential consequence of mismanaging this data dependency?

options.title: Change in ability of model to be part of a streaming ingest
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. Your model structure doesn't change just because it's easier or harder to leave reviews.

options.title: Losses in prediction quality
options.rationale: Correct! For example, a review might be easier to write, and so your prediction of whether someone will leave a review (whether good or bad) is too low because it was trained on reviews that resulted from the older, harder-to-use user interface

options.title: Change in model serving signature
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. Your model structure doesn't change just because it's easier or harder to leave reviews.

questions.stem: If each of your examples is large in terms of size and requires parsing, and your model is relatively simple and shallow, your model is likely to be:

options.title: I/O bound, so you should look for ways to store data more efficiently and ways to parallelize the reads.
options.rationale: Correct! Your ML training will be I/O bound if the number of inputs is large or  heterogeneous (requires parsing) or if the model is so small that the compute requirements are trivial. This also tends to be the case if the input data is on a storage system with low throughput. If you are I/O bound, look at storing the data more efficiently, storing the data on a storage system with higher throughput, or parallelizing the reads. Although it is not ideal, you might consider reducing the batch size so that you are reading less data in each step.

options.title: CPU-bound, so you should use GPUs or TPUs.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. This doesn't sound like computational power is your limiting factor.

options.title: Latency-bound, so you should use faster hardware
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. Review I/O-bound, CPU-bound and memory-bound models.

options.rationale: Correct. Padding extends the area of an image in which a convolutional neural network processes. The approach adds a border around the input values in the original image. Therefore, it helps you maintain the same size across the input and the output of the convolutional layer.

options.title: Strides
options.rationale: This answer is incorrect. Strides are the size of the step by which the filter slides across the input image. The default step size is 1 pixel in both directions. questions.stem: What are some ways you can address the cold-start problem that can occur for new users of a collaborative filter recommendation system? There could be more than one answer.

options.title: Rely on a content-based method instead for new users.
options.rationale: Content-based systems require that we either base our recommendations solely on the properties of the items, by looking for similar items for example, or that we have representations of our users in the same embedding space of our items. For a trivial example, by asking users which genres they prefer, we could make content-based recommendations using representations of items with genres as features.

options.title: Ask the user for some basic preferences.
options.rationale: With only a few preferences, we could classify users into different personas we've derived across our user-base and base our recommendations on the preferences of this entire group.

options.title: Give up and ask new users to make their own recommendations.
options.rationale: Power users may be willing to help but their capacity won't scale with your service.

options.title: Ask the new user's friends to recommend items they think would be relevant.
options.rationale: Our friends are not always the best product recommenders, as anyone who has ever gotten a weird gift knows. Additionally, it means your service would have little value to users who don't already have friends on the site, which might very likely be the case when the product launches in a new country.

questions.stem: Suppose you want to build a collaborative filter to suggest new hiking trails for users. The problem is you don't have any good explicit user ratings for trails. What feature might be useful for creating an implicit measure of a user's rating for a trail instead?

options.title: The length of the trail.
options.rationale: The length of the trail is constant across all users so it can't be a measure of an individual user's rating of a particular trail.

options.title: The number of times the user hiked that trail
options.rationale: The decision to hike a trail can be reasonably interpreted as an implicit measure of user preference.

options.title: The distance of the trail to the user's home.
options.rationale: Distance to the trail better captured using a knowledge-based recommendation system.

options.title: The number of times all users hiked that trail.
options.rationale: The number of times all users hiked a trail would be a useful measure of objective or consensus quality but it would not be able to capture an individual users' preference.

questions.stem: Choose the correct three answers. What are some potential techniques to determine how similar two items are? There could be more than one answer.

options.title: Plot the two items in the embedding space and simply visually inspect to see how close they are on a graph by looking briefly.
options.rationale: Visual inspection is great for quick decisions but is not rigorous enough or scaleable for anything formal.

options.title: Measure the cosine similarity between the two items in an embedding space.
options.rationale: Correct

options.title: Compare the norms (which are directionless) of the two items in an embedding space to see if they are similar.
options.rationale: Because norms are directionless scalars, two vectors can have identical norms and sit in completely different parts of the vector space.

options.title: Count how many features the two items have in common.
options.rationale: Correct

options.title: Compute the inner product between the two items in an embedding space.
options.rationale: Correct

questions.stem: When building a content-based recommender system, it's important to express both your items and users using the same embedding space (that is. the same dimensions and features).

options.title: True.
options.rationale: We calculate our recommendation using the product of the user embedding and the item embedding, so it's critical that the dimensions of these two embeddings are the same.

options.title: False
options.rationale: Think again about the computation we perform to generate predictions for a given user: we multiply a user-feature vector by an item-feature vector to get a prediction. In order for this multiplication to make sense, the shape of the vectors and the meaning of each dimension need to be the same.

questions.stem: ALS and WALS create embedding tables for both users and items. Because these are held in memory, it's important to plan for their size. How big would you expect the embedding table for the users to be?

options.title: Proportional to the number of users squared.
options.rationale: The embeddings table has a number of rows equal to the number of users and a number of columns equal to the embedding size, which is a hyper parameter. While the embedding size could theoretically be the same as the number of users, in practice, this number is never that big.

options.title: Proportional to k, the number of dimensions in your embedding space.
options.rationale: Correct

options.title: Proportional to the number of users.
options.rationale: Correct

options.title: Proportional to the number of users multiplied by the number of items.
options.rationale: The original sparse rating matrix has these dimensions, not the embeddings.

questions.stem: You want to create a hybrid recommendation system to suggest music for new users on your music streaming app that just launched. New users are asked to rate a few bands they like. You have reliable data for artist name, song name, album name, etc. Each song is labeled for genre at a coarse level (rock, pop, etc.). Which component of your recommendation system will likely perform the best?

options.title: The collaborative filtering component.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. The performance of the collaborative filtering component is determined by the density of the ratings matrix. Because our app just launched, and because explicit feedback is so rare, our collaborative filtering recommendations will likely be poor.

options.title: The knowledge-based component.
options.rationale: This answer is correct! Because the user has entered some basic preferences, and because we have reliable metadata for each song, we can recommend songs with the same metadata or allow users to find such songs on their own.

options.title: The content-based component.
options.rationale: This answer is not correct. The performance of the content-based component is determined by the quality of the representations of the content. In this case, we know very little about each song. Our genre labels are coarse and we have no representations of the raw audio itself.
